newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore offers telecoms firms S$100 mln grants.
newsitem.headline: Singapore offers telecoms firms S$100 mln grants.

text.p: Singapore said on Tuesday it would award Singapore $100 million (US$69.44 million) in grants to local telecommunications companies to improve their networks and help them compete in the global telecoms market.
The scheme, announced by Communications Minister Mah Bow Tan, coincided with the deregulation of Singapore's mobile phone and pager markets on Tuesday.
The Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (TAS) said in a statement the development grants would be awarded for projects that encouraged technology transfers by foreign companies.
To be eligible, companies must develop Singapore's role as a business hub, promote strategic development of information communications, enhance telecommunications companies and benefit consumers.
TAS said it wanted to ensure Singapore's telecommunications infrastructure and services remained world-class to help businesses compete in an increasingly competitive world.
From Tuesday, Singapore's state-owned telephone company Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel) lost its complete monopoly of local telephone services.
It now faces one new competitor, MobileOne, in the mobile phone market and three new rival pager services.
MobileOne is a joint venture of Britain's Cable & Wireless, Hong Kong Telecommunications, Keppel Telecom and Singapore Press Holdings.
Tuesday's deregulation is Singapore's first move towards freeing up the whole of its market.
Next year TAS is due to announce one or two new licences to compete directly with SingTel to provide land-based basic telephone networks.
